description:
This PR brings in two features that I really enjoyed implementing.   

1. The first is automatic conversions between Gaussian and SI unit systems. The electromagnetic charge is defined differently in these two systems, and so the units system as-is does not 

2. The second is "equivalencies". These are conversions between quantities which do not have the same units but a related by a constant, e.g., mass/energy, wavelength/energy/frequency, temperature/sound speed, mass/Schwarzschild radius, etc. 

Probably the best way to see these in action is to look at my edit of one of the units notebooks, which I have put into NBViewer for easy reading. Read the sections "Electrostatic/Electromagnetic Units" and "Unit Equivalencies": 

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/jzuhone/1f916b20e8b46cb77374

Other things to note:

1. The dimensions have changed, e.g. `dimensions.charge` is now `dimensions.charge_cgs`, though I have added aliases for backwards-compatibility.

2. `dimensions.current_mks` is now an mks base unit.  

3. While I was at it I added Planck units. 

4. Docs and tests have been added. 

UPDATE 1: Addressed @ChrisMalone and @ngoldbaum's suggestions.

UPDATE 2: Thanks to @ChrisMalone and @ngoldbaum for their suggestions which improved the PR.

UPDATE 3: Fixed merge conflicts.

pullrequest.title: Conversions for different electromagnetic unit systems, Unit equivalencies

content.raw:
This looks really cool John!  

One question about the `to_equivalent` method: Would it be possible to detect the available `Equivalence` classes for `self`, and then apply the `Equivalence` corresponding to the input `unit`?  Maybe there would be some degeneracies that would make this unpossible, but I haven't thought about this as much as you.
content.html:
This looks really cool John!

One question about the to_equivalent method: Would it be possible to detect the available Equivalence classes for self, and then apply the Equivalence corresponding to the input unit? Maybe there would be some degeneracies that would make this unpossible, but I haven't thought about this as much as you.

pullrequest.title: Conversions for different electromagnetic unit systems, Unit equivalencies

pullrequest.title: Conversions for different electromagnetic unit systems, Unit equivalencies

content.raw:
Another thing I noticed (although not part of your PR, but illuminated by your notebook) is that `in_units` doesn't seem to completely respect `code_` units.  For example, you have

    Cell dx in code units: 
    [ 0.03125     0.03125     0.03125    ...,  0.00012207  0.00012207
      0.00012207] code_length 
    Cell dx in megaparsecs: 
    [ 0.03125327  0.03125327  0.03125327 ...,  0.00012208  0.00012208
      0.00012208] Mpc

Shouldn't they be exactly equivalent?  Would it be possible to add, in `in_units`, a check to see if the requested units are equal to code units, and then to return that exactly if that were the case?
content.html:
Another thing I noticed (although not part of your PR, but illuminated by your notebook) is that in_units doesn't seem to completely respect code_ units. For example, you have

Cell dx in code units: 
[ 0.03125     0.03125     0.03125    ...,  0.00012207  0.00012207
  0.00012207] code_length 
Cell dx in megaparsecs: 
[ 0.03125327  0.03125327  0.03125327 ...,  0.00012208  0.00012208
  0.00012208] Mpc

Shouldn't they be exactly equivalent? Would it be possible to add, in in_units, a check to see if the requested units are equal to code units, and then to return that exactly if that were the case?

pullrequest.title: Conversions for different electromagnetic unit systems, Unit equivalencies

content.raw:
Ok @ngoldbaum, so here are the results:

Before this PR:   

yt.units.yt_array.time_make: 0.118 +/- 0.05 ms, 1.00x numpy   
yt.units.yt_array.time_ops: 4.438 +/- 0.41 ms, 20.91x numpy   
yt.units.yt_array.time_ufuncs: 7.251 +/- 5.86 ms, 1.51x numpy   

After this PR:   

yt.units.yt_array.time_make: 0.128 +/- 0.04 ms, 0.99x numpy   
yt.units.yt_array.time_ops: 6.840 +/- 0.71 ms, 31.40x numpy   
yt.units.yt_array.time_ufuncs: 8.200 +/- 5.80 ms, 1.74x numpy   

So clearly I have slowed things down quite a bit, actually--need to figure out where I should look.
content.html:
Ok Nathan Goldbaum, so here are the results:

Before this PR:

yt.units.yt_array.time_make: 0.118 +/- 0.05 ms, 1.00x numpy
yt.units.yt_array.time_ops: 4.438 +/- 0.41 ms, 20.91x numpy
yt.units.yt_array.time_ufuncs: 7.251 +/- 5.86 ms, 1.51x numpy

After this PR:

yt.units.yt_array.time_make: 0.128 +/- 0.04 ms, 0.99x numpy
yt.units.yt_array.time_ops: 6.840 +/- 0.71 ms, 31.40x numpy
yt.units.yt_array.time_ufuncs: 8.200 +/- 5.80 ms, 1.74x numpy

So clearly I have slowed things down quite a bit, actually--need to figure out where I should look.

content.html: Never mind, I found the bottleneck--looking for a solution now.

pullrequest.title: Conversions for different electromagnetic unit systems, Unit equivalencies

content.raw:
This is really awesome John.  I think this can go in as is.  I'm ok with the performance penalty, and we can iterate on polishing performance in the units module.  I have other improvements I want to make there as well.

My one comment is that it would be really nice to see examples for the number density equivalency, since it's something I see people ask about a lot.  It could also use some scary words about only being valid for an ideal gas with fixed mean molecular weight.
content.html:
This is really awesome John. I think this can go in as is. I'm ok with the performance penalty, and we can iterate on polishing performance in the units module. I have other improvements I want to make there as well.

My one comment is that it would be really nice to see examples for the number density equivalency, since it's something I see people ask about a lot. It could also use some scary words about only being valid for an ideal gas with fixed mean molecular weight.
